awd_titl_txt: UNS: New Approaches to Catalyst Screening and Development
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Stephen G DiMagno
Proposal Number: 1500076

Catalysts are materials that promote chemical reactions for production of industrial chemicals, fuels, plastics, and pharmaceuticals from a wide variety of raw materials.  A fundamental scientific challenge is to design the catalyst to be active for a specific type of reaction.  In Nature, biological catalysts called enzymes have very specific catalyst functions.  The overall goal of this project is to use enzymes to help guide the design of new catalyst materials.  The key novelty is that the enzyme screening process reports if the catalyst candidate is capable of performing stereochemistry, which is fundamental to making many valuable compounds and pharmaceuticals.  In this continuing effort, complex chemical reactions involving stereochemistry will be developed and studied.  One possible target is a more efficient approach to synthesis of commercial drugs like Pregabalin.  The educational activities of the project include training of graduate students and post-doctoral research associates at the interface of biology and chemistry, as well as high school student outreach through Chemistry Day.

This proposed continuation of NSF-supported research focuses on the use enzymes to help identify catalysts of interest for synthetic organic chemistry through a process called In Situ Enzymatic Screening (ISES).  The reporting enzymes used in ISES are chiral sensors that provide information the relative rate, stereoselectivity, and substrate scope of catalyst candidates.  This renewal proposal will use ISES tools and previous discoveries from ISES screening outcomes to advance three Aims.  The first Aim is to extend both the Rh- and Pd-mediated (pseudo) halometalation/carbocyclization transformations various ring sizes, explore competition between post-cyclization/cross-metathesis and ring-closing metathesis, examine other nucleophiles, and test mechanistic postulates, particularly regarding the stereochemical course of the carbocyclization step.  The second Aim is develop the scope of the ISES method, with specific focus on developing viable enzyme couples for both the diethyl phosphate leaving group and for the acetate leaving group through a three enzyme couple.  Towards this end, candidate dialkyl phosphatase reporting enzymes will be expressed from E. aerogenes, and this enzyme will be used, in tandem with an alcohol dehydrogenase, to screen for metal-ligand mediated allylic substitution directly that involves displacement of the diethyl phosphate.  The third Aim seeks to identify viable catalytic combinations for the desymmetrization of 3-substituted oxetanes and N-protected azetidines via nucleophilic-opening.  If successful, this chemistry would provide a fundamentally new entry into the asymmetric synthesis of beta(2)-amino acids (AAs) and of gamma(3)-AAs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Under NSF-CHE support, the Berkowitz group has been developing the  In Situ Enzymatic Screening (ISES) approach to discovery of new reaction modalities and to the identification of new catalyst-ligand combinations.  In this method, enzymes report directly on the formation of (by)product with time, allowing the experimentalist to rank catalytic combinations in real time, without the need to draw aliquots or quench the reaction.  The ISES method has been identified as one of the important methods for catalyst screening by leaders in the field; e.g. Frank Glorius (Universitaet Muenster) in his 2014 Nature Chemistry overview (https://www.nature.com/articles/nchem.2062) and  Eric Anslyn  (UT-Austin), Christian Wolf (Georgetown) and  Leo Joyce (Merck Process Chemistry) in their 2018 JACS Perspective (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/jacs.8b06607).   Moreover, in the this grant  period, our own invited overview of the method was published in Current Protocols in Chemical Biology (https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/cpch.30).

Heretofore, this real time enzymatic screening method has led to (i) the first examples of asymmetric Ni-based allylic amination, opening up important new avenues for this earth-abundant transition metal; (ii) to a new bromorhodiation/carbocyclization transformation and (iii) to the development of useful new chiral salen ligands for asymmetric catalysis, based upon 1,2-diamines derived a beta-pinene and from (carba)fructopyranose.

The principal outcome under this cycle of this NSF-CHE grant was the discovery, optimization and development of a new transformation with the enzymatic screening method, one that initially appeared as a single hit in a field over 1000 reactions being screened.  We  call this transformation the thiocyanopalladation-carbocyclization reaction and we believe that this chemistry will find interest and application in the synthetic organic chemistry, organometallic chemistry and medicinal chemistry/chemical biology communities. The transformation is a Pd(II)-catalyzed process that results in the formation of both a C-SCN bond and a new C-C bond, with cyclization.   If there is a pre-existing stereocenter at the allylic position or propargylic position in the substrate, high levels of 1,2-anti or 1,3-syn diastereocontrol are achieved, respectively.  The cyclization products are shown to be highly synthetically maleable, with the SCN moiety lending itself to a variety of tailoring reactions, demonstrating the potential value of this chemistry for the construction of chemical biology libraries.

Other notable achievements include the expression, characterization and application of new reporting enzymes to other types of reaction screens, including those at elevated temperature and those with alternative leaving groups.   In addition, this cycle saw a collaboration with Masato Kitamura (Nagoya University, Japan) come to fruition with the application of a family of cationic ruthenium (II/IV) catalysts developed in Nagoya in new variants of allylic substitution chemistry.

 Broader Impacts:

This research has had a number of important broader impacts, including providing interdisciplinary training for a diverse group undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral student co-workers.  Skills sets learned range from protein biochemistry/enzymology to organometallic chemistry and  stereocontrolled organic synthesis to analytical chemistry and kinetics. Under this grant, four graduate students successfully defended their Ph.D. dissertations; two are currently engaged in teaching positions in academia at both a public and a private university; the other two successfully competed for prestigious postdoctoral positions and are pursuing industrial career paths in the pharmaceutical and biotech sectors. Women, students from traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM and international students are all represented in the group, and team members actively participate in national American Chemical Society meetings.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2019
Modified by: David B Berkowitz
